categories.description: Fundamental patterns in how people express themselves and interact with others

subcategories.name: Assertive Communication
subcategories.description: Direct, honest expression while respecting others

behaviors.name: Clear Boundary Setting
behaviors.definition: Directly stating personal limits and expectations without aggression or apology
examples: I'm not comfortable discussing this topic right now
I need some time alone to process this
That doesn't work for me, but here's what could
unhealthy_indicators: Can become rigid if boundaries are never flexible

behaviors.name: I-Statement Usage
behaviors.definition: Expressing feelings and needs from personal perspective rather than blaming
examples: I feel hurt when plans change last minute
I need more clarity about expectations
I'm struggling to understand your perspective

behaviors.name: Direct Requests
behaviors.definition: Clearly asking for what you need without hints or manipulation
examples: Could you please help me with this?
I'd like us to spend more time together
I need you to listen without offering solutions right now
healthy_indicators: Respects others' ability to say no

subcategories.name: Passive Communication
subcategories.description: Avoiding direct expression, often prioritizing others' needs over own

behaviors.name: Indirect Hinting
behaviors.definition: Suggesting needs or feelings without stating them directly
examples: It would be nice if someone helped around here
I guess I'll just do it myself then
Some people think we should leave soon...
healthy_indicators: Can soften difficult messages in certain cultures
May preserve harmony in specific contexts
unhealthy_indicators: Breeds resentment when hints aren't received
Puts burden on others to mind-read
behaviors.frequency_note: Occasional use normal; frequent use problematic

behaviors.name: Over-Apologizing
behaviors.definition: Excessive apologizing for things that don't warrant apology
examples: I'm sorry, this might be a stupid question
Sorry for existing in this space
behaviors.frequency_note: Frequent use indicates self-esteem work needed

behaviors.name: Conflict Avoidance
behaviors.definition: Actively steering away from disagreements or difficult topics
examples: Let's just not talk about it
unhealthy_indicators: Partner may feel dismissed or unheard

behaviors.name: People Pleasing
behaviors.definition: Prioritizing others' approval and happiness over personal needs
examples: Whatever you want is fine with me
Agreeing to plans you don't want
healthy_indicators: Shows care for others in moderation
unhealthy_indicators: Attracts those who exploit this tendency

subcategories.name: Aggressive Communication
subcategories.description: Expressing needs in ways that violate others' rights or dignity

behaviors.name: Verbal Attacks
behaviors.definition: Using words to hurt, demean, or intimidate
examples: No one else would put up with you
behaviors.frequency_note: Any occurrence is concerning; pattern is abusive

behaviors.name: Intimidation Tactics
behaviors.definition: Using fear, size, volume, or implied threats to control
examples: You don't want to see me really angry
behaviors.frequency_note: Any occurrence is a red flag

behaviors.name: Dismissiveness
behaviors.definition: Treating others' thoughts, feelings, or contributions as worthless

subcategories.name: Passive-Aggressive Communication
subcategories.description: Indirect expression of negative feelings through subtle actions

behaviors.name: Silent Treatment
behaviors.definition: Withdrawing communication as punishment or manipulation
examples: Refusing to speak for extended periods
healthy_indicators: Brief space to cool down is healthy
Communicating need for space is healthy
unhealthy_indicators: Creates anxiety and walking on eggshells

behaviors.name: Weaponized Sarcasm
behaviors.definition: Using sarcasm to express hostility while maintaining deniability
examples: Wow, what a surprise (when not surprised)
healthy_indicators: Playful sarcasm between consenting parties is fine

behaviors.name: Backhanded Compliments
behaviors.definition: Compliments that contain embedded insults or criticism
examples: You look good for your age
That's actually not bad, coming from you

behaviors.name: Deliberate Inefficiency
behaviors.definition: Purposely doing tasks poorly to avoid future requests
examples: Doing chores so badly partner redoes them
Taking excessive time on simple requests
behaviors.frequency_note: Pattern indicates resistance to discuss issues

categories.description: Behaviors used to control, deceive, or unfairly influence others

subcategories.name: Gaslighting
subcategories.description: Making someone question their own reality, memory, or perceptions

behaviors.name: Reality Denial
behaviors.definition: Flatly denying events that occurred or statements that were made
unhealthy_indicators: Causes victim to doubt their memory
Psychological abuse that causes lasting damage
behaviors.frequency_note: Any pattern is serious psychological abuse

behaviors.name: Perception Invalidation
behaviors.definition: Telling someone their interpretation of events is wrong or crazy
healthy_indicators: None when used to dismiss legitimate concerns
unhealthy_indicators: Victim loses trust in own judgment
behaviors.frequency_note: Pattern erodes victim's sense of self

behaviors.name: Historical Revisionism
behaviors.definition: Changing the narrative of past events to suit current needs
examples: That's not how it happened at all
unhealthy_indicators: Creates alternate reality controlled by manipulator
behaviors.frequency_note: Systematic rewriting of history is abuse

subcategories.name: DARVO
subcategories.description: Deny, Attack, Reverse Victim and Offender - common abuser tactic

behaviors.name: Deny the Behavior
behaviors.definition: First step: flatly denying the problematic behavior occurred
healthy_indicators: Genuine denial of false accusations is valid
unhealthy_indicators: Pattern of denial across multiple issues
behaviors.frequency_note: Part of DARVO pattern is highly concerning

behaviors.name: Attack the Accuser
behaviors.definition: Second step: attacking the person who raised the concern
unhealthy_indicators: Shifts focus from behavior to accuser
behaviors.frequency_note: Attacking accusers is manipulation red flag

behaviors.name: Reverse Victim and Offender
behaviors.definition: Third step: claiming to be the real victim while victim is aggressor
examples: You're abusing ME by bringing this up
I'm the one being attacked here
Look what you made me do
unhealthy_indicators: Real victim ends up comforting offender
Victim feels guilty for raising concerns
behaviors.frequency_note: Classic abuser pattern - serious red flag

subcategories.name: Emotional Manipulation
subcategories.description: Using emotions to control or influence others unfairly

behaviors.name: Guilt Tripping
behaviors.definition: Inducing guilt to manipulate behavior or decisions
examples: After everything I've done for you
I guess I'm just not important to you
unhealthy_indicators: Recipient acts from guilt, not genuine desire

behaviors.name: Love Bombing
behaviors.definition: Overwhelming someone with affection to gain control or forgiveness
healthy_indicators: Healthy when matched by consistent behavior
unhealthy_indicators: Creates sense of debt or obligation
Intensity not sustainable or matched by respect
behaviors.frequency_note: Cycles of love bombing and devaluation are abuse

behaviors.name: Emotional Blackmail
behaviors.definition: Using fear, obligation, or guilt to control behavior
examples: If you leave, I'll hurt myself
You owe me after what I sacrificed
A good partner would do this for me

behaviors.name: Playing Victim
behaviors.definition: Consistently portraying oneself as victim to avoid accountability
examples: I can never do anything right
You're just like everyone else who hurt me
healthy_indicators: Genuine victimization exists and is valid

behaviors.name: Triangulation
behaviors.definition: Bringing third parties into conflicts to manipulate dynamics
examples: My friend agrees you're being unreasonable
My ex never had this problem
Everyone thinks I'm right about this
healthy_indicators: Seeking outside perspective can be healthy

subcategories.name: Control Tactics
subcategories.description: Behaviors aimed at controlling another person

behaviors.name: Isolation
behaviors.definition: Separating someone from their support network
examples: Your friends are a bad influence
I should be enough for you
behaviors.frequency_note: Any isolation attempts are serious red flag

behaviors.name: Financial Control
behaviors.definition: Using money to control or limit partner's freedom
examples: Why do you need your own account?
You have to ask before spending anything
behaviors.frequency_note: Financial abuse is serious domestic abuse

behaviors.name: Monitoring/Surveillance
behaviors.definition: Excessive tracking of partner's movements, communications, activities

categories.description: Psychological strategies used to cope with anxiety, stress, or threats to ego

subcategories.name: Primitive Defenses
subcategories.description: Less mature defenses typically formed in early development

behaviors.name: Denial
behaviors.definition: Refusing to accept reality or facts to avoid anxiety
healthy_indicators: Brief denial can buffer initial shock
unhealthy_indicators: Can enable harmful situations to continue
behaviors.frequency_note: Prolonged denial prevents growth and resolution

behaviors.name: Projection
behaviors.definition: Attributing one's own unacceptable thoughts or feelings to others
examples: You're the one who's angry (when they're angry)
You don't care about me (when they're withdrawn)

behaviors.name: Splitting (Black and White Thinking)
behaviors.definition: Viewing things as all good or all bad with no middle ground
examples: You're either with me or against me
This is the best/worst thing ever
unhealthy_indicators: Others feel they can't make mistakes
behaviors.frequency_note: Common in personality disorders; therapy helpful

subcategories.name: Neurotic Defenses
subcategories.description: More sophisticated but still problematic defense mechanisms

behaviors.name: Rationalization
behaviors.definition: Creating logical explanations for behaviors driven by emotions
examples: I had to yell because you weren't listening
I deserve this because I worked hard

behaviors.name: Intellectualization
behaviors.definition: Using abstract thinking to distance from emotional content

behaviors.name: Displacement
behaviors.definition: Redirecting emotions from true source to safer target
examples: Bad day at work → snap at partner
Angry at parent → yell at child
unhealthy_indicators: Creates confusion about what's really wrong

behaviors.name: Regression
behaviors.definition: Reverting to less mature behaviors under stress
healthy_indicators: Brief regression for comfort is normal

subcategories.name: Mature Defenses
subcategories.description: Healthy coping mechanisms that can be adaptive

behaviors.name: Sublimation
behaviors.definition: Channeling negative emotions into constructive activities
examples: Using anger to fuel intense workout
unhealthy_indicators: Can become avoidance if emotions never directly addressed
behaviors.frequency_note: Generally healthy when balanced with processing

behaviors.name: Humor as Coping
behaviors.definition: Using humor to manage difficult emotions or situations
examples: Making light of a stressful situation
behaviors.frequency_note: Healthy when not avoiding all seriousness

behaviors.name: Anticipation
behaviors.definition: Preparing emotionally and practically for future challenges
behaviors.frequency_note: Healthy when balanced with present awareness

categories.description: Patterns related to how we form and maintain emotional bonds

subcategories.name: Secure Attachment Behaviors
subcategories.description: Patterns indicating healthy attachment and relating

behaviors.name: Comfortable with Intimacy
behaviors.definition: Able to be close without anxiety or avoidance

behaviors.name: Effective Emotional Communication
behaviors.definition: Expressing needs and hearing partner's needs clearly

behaviors.name: Healthy Interdependence
behaviors.definition: Balanced reliance on self and others

subcategories.name: Anxious Attachment Behaviors
subcategories.description: Patterns indicating fear of abandonment and need for reassurance

behaviors.name: Excessive Reassurance Seeking
behaviors.definition: Repeatedly seeking validation that relationship is secure
behaviors.frequency_note: Chronic seeking indicates attachment work needed

behaviors.name: Protest Behaviors
behaviors.definition: Actions designed to get partner's attention when feeling insecure

behaviors.name: Relationship Hypervigilance
behaviors.definition: Constantly scanning for signs of rejection or abandonment
examples: Analyzing every text for hidden meaning
Noticing every mood change in partner
healthy_indicators: Attentiveness can be positive in moderation
unhealthy_indicators: Often sees threats that aren't there

behaviors.name: Enmeshment/Fusion
behaviors.definition: Losing boundaries between self and partner
healthy_indicators: Some blending in close relationships is normal

subcategories.name: Avoidant Attachment Behaviors
subcategories.description: Patterns indicating discomfort with closeness and emotional suppression

behaviors.name: Emotional Distancing
behaviors.definition: Creating emotional space when closeness increases
healthy_indicators: Some space for processing is healthy

behaviors.name: Extreme Self-Reliance
behaviors.definition: Refusing to depend on others even when appropriate

behaviors.name: Deactivating Strategies
behaviors.definition: Mental techniques to suppress attachment needs
examples: Convincing self you don't need closeness

categories.description: Patterns in how emotions are experienced, expressed, and managed

subcategories.name: Healthy Regulation
subcategories.description: Adaptive ways of managing emotions

behaviors.name: Emotional Awareness
behaviors.definition: Ability to identify and name emotional states
examples: This brings up sadness for me

behaviors.name: Self-Soothing
behaviors.definition: Ability to calm oneself during distress
healthy_indicators: Reduces reliance on others for regulation

behaviors.name: Repair Attempts
behaviors.definition: Efforts to de-escalate conflict and reconnect
examples: Can we pause and start over?
unhealthy_indicators: Can become avoidance of necessary conflict

subcategories.name: Emotional Dysregulation
subcategories.description: Difficulty managing emotional responses

behaviors.name: Emotional Flooding
behaviors.definition: Overwhelming emotional response that impairs functioning
examples: Unable to think clearly when upset
behaviors.frequency_note: Frequent flooding indicates regulation work needed

behaviors.name: High Emotional Reactivity
behaviors.definition: Intense, quick emotional responses disproportionate to trigger

behaviors.name: Emotional Suppression
behaviors.definition: Chronically pushing down or ignoring emotions
unhealthy_indicators: Emotions leak out in other ways

categories.description: Patterns in how disagreements and tensions are handled

subcategories.name: Constructive Conflict
subcategories.description: Healthy ways of navigating disagreement

behaviors.name: Active Listening
behaviors.definition: Fully attending to and seeking to understand partner's perspective
examples: Putting aside own response to truly hear

behaviors.name: Taking Responsibility
behaviors.definition: Owning one's part in conflicts without defensiveness
examples: You're right, I shouldn't have done that
I can see how my actions contributed
I'm sorry for my part in this

behaviors.name: Compromise Seeking
behaviors.definition: Working toward solutions that address both parties' needs
examples: What would work for both of us?
Can we find a middle ground?
I'll do X if you can do Y

behaviors.name: Taking Constructive Breaks
behaviors.definition: Pausing heated discussions to regulate before continuing
examples: I need 20 minutes to calm down
Let's continue this after we've both cooled off
unhealthy_indicators: Can become avoidance if break never ends

subcategories.name: Destructive Conflict
subcategories.description: Patterns that damage relationships during disagreement

behaviors.name: Criticism (vs. Complaint)
behaviors.definition: Attacking partner's character rather than specific behavior
examples: You're so lazy (vs. I wish you'd help more)
You never think about anyone but yourself

behaviors.name: Contempt
behaviors.definition: Treating partner with disrespect, disgust, or superiority
behaviors.frequency_note: Any contempt is serious warning sign

behaviors.name: Defensiveness
behaviors.definition: Protecting self by deflecting, making excuses, or counter-attacking
examples: I only did that because you...

behaviors.name: Stonewalling
behaviors.definition: Withdrawing from interaction, shutting down
healthy_indicators: Taking a communicated break is healthy

behaviors.name: Kitchen Sinking
behaviors.definition: Bringing up multiple past issues during current conflict
examples: And another thing, last month you...
This is just like when you...

categories.description: Patterns related to building, maintaining, or damaging trust

subcategories.name: Trust-Building Behaviors
subcategories.description: Actions that create and strengthen trust

behaviors.name: Consistency
behaviors.definition: Behavior matches words over time

behaviors.name: Transparency
behaviors.definition: Open sharing of relevant information

behaviors.name: Vulnerability
behaviors.definition: Sharing deeper feelings, fears, and authentic self
behaviors.frequency_note: Builds intimacy when mutual and paced

subcategories.name: Trust-Damaging Behaviors
subcategories.description: Actions that erode or destroy trust

behaviors.name: Dishonesty
behaviors.definition: Lying, omitting important information, or deceiving

behaviors.name: Broken Promises
behaviors.definition: Failing to follow through on commitments

behaviors.name: Betrayal
behaviors.definition: Major violations of trust and relationship agreements
behaviors.frequency_note: Single major betrayal can end relationship

categories.description: Thinking patterns that affect communication and relationships

subcategories.name: Cognitive Distortions
subcategories.description: Biased thinking patterns that affect perception

behaviors.name: Mind Reading
behaviors.definition: Assuming you know what others think without checking
examples: I know you think I'm stupid
unhealthy_indicators: Doesn't allow partner to speak for self
behaviors.frequency_note: Check assumptions before acting on them

behaviors.name: Catastrophizing
behaviors.definition: Expecting the worst possible outcome
examples: If we fight, we'll definitely break up
One mistake means everything is ruined

behaviors.name: Personalization
behaviors.definition: Assuming everything relates to or is caused by you
examples: They're in a bad mood because of me
That comment was definitely about me

behaviors.name: All-or-Nothing Thinking
behaviors.definition: Seeing things in extremes with no middle ground
examples: You always do this / You never help
If it's not perfect, it's failure

behaviors.name: Emotional Reasoning
behaviors.definition: Assuming feelings reflect reality
examples: I feel unloved, so I must be unlovable
I feel anxious, so something must be wrong
I feel guilty, so I must have done something bad

subcategories.name: Healthy Thinking Patterns
subcategories.description: Adaptive cognitive approaches

behaviors.name: Perspective Taking
behaviors.definition: Ability to see situations from others' viewpoint
examples: I can see why you'd feel that way
From your perspective, that makes sense
Considering what they might be going through

behaviors.name: Nuanced Thinking
behaviors.definition: Seeing complexity and shades of gray
examples: This is complicated, both things can be true
I understand the good intentions even if the impact was bad
There's more to this than one explanation

behaviors.name: Growth Mindset
behaviors.definition: Believing people and relationships can change and improve
examples: We can work on this together
I'm still developing in this area
unhealthy_indicators: Can enable staying in bad situations too long

categories.description: Patterns related to personal limits and respecting others' limits

subcategories.name: Healthy Boundary Behaviors
subcategories.description: Appropriate setting and respecting of limits

behaviors.name: Clear Boundary Communication
behaviors.definition: Expressing limits directly and respectfully
examples: I'm not available to talk after 10pm
That topic is off-limits for me
I need advance notice for plans

behaviors.name: Respecting Others' Boundaries
behaviors.definition: Honoring limits set by others without pushback
examples: Not pressuring when limit is set

behaviors.name: Appropriate Boundary Flexibility
behaviors.definition: Adjusting boundaries based on context while maintaining core limits
unhealthy_indicators: Flexibility shouldn't mean abandoning important limits

subcategories.name: Boundary Violations
subcategories.description: Inappropriate crossing of personal limits

behaviors.name: Boundary Pushing
behaviors.definition: Testing or pressuring against stated limits
examples: Are you sure? Just this once?
Repeatedly asking after being told no

behaviors.name: Boundary Dismissal
behaviors.definition: Treating others' limits as unimportant or invalid
examples: Acting as if boundary wasn't stated

behaviors.name: Porous/Weak Boundaries
behaviors.definition: Difficulty maintaining own limits
examples: Saying yes when wanting to say no
Taking on others' emotions as own

behaviors.name: Rigid/Excessive Boundaries
behaviors.definition: Inflexible limits that prevent intimacy

categories.description: Behaviors that strengthen and nourish relationships

subcategories.name: Appreciation & Affection
subcategories.description: Expressing love and gratitude

behaviors.name: Expressing Appreciation
behaviors.definition: Regularly acknowledging partner's positive qualities and actions
behaviors.frequency_note: Aim for 5:1 positive to negative ratio

behaviors.name: Appropriate Physical Affection
behaviors.definition: Consensual physical expressions of care and connection

behaviors.name: Verbal Affirmation
behaviors.definition: Expressing love, admiration, and positive regard verbally
examples: You mean so much to me

subcategories.name: Support Behaviors
subcategories.description: Being there for partner

behaviors.name: Emotional Support
behaviors.definition: Providing comfort, validation, and presence during difficulties

behaviors.name: Practical Support
behaviors.definition: Helping with tangible tasks and responsibilities
examples: Helping with chores during busy times
Taking on extra responsibilities when partner is struggling

behaviors.name: Celebrating Successes
behaviors.definition: Enthusiastically sharing in partner's wins and achievements

subcategories.name: Relationship Maintenance
subcategories.description: Ongoing efforts to nurture the relationship

behaviors.name: Quality Time
behaviors.definition: Dedicated, focused time together
behaviors.frequency_note: Regular quality time essential for connection

behaviors.name: Ongoing Curiosity
behaviors.definition: Continued interest in partner's inner world
examples: Wanting to know their thoughts and dreams

behaviors.name: Creating Shared Meaning
behaviors.definition: Building rituals, traditions, and shared purpose
examples: Creating traditions unique to the relationship

metadata.disclaimer: This library is for educational purposes. It is not a substitute for professional mental health support. If you are in an abusive situation, please reach out to appropriate support services.
